1.content: A wise judge shall judge his people, and the government of a prudent man shall be steady.

2.content: As the judge of the people is himself, so also are his ministers: and what manner of man the ruler of a city is, such also are they that dwell therein.

3.content: An unwise king shall be the ruin of his people: and cities shall be inhabited through the prudence of the rulers.

4.content: The power of the earth is in the hand of God, and in his time he will raise up a profitable ruler over it.

5.content: The prosperity of man is in the hand of God, and upon the person of the scribe he shall lay his honour.

6.content: Remember not any injury done thee by thy neighbour, and do thou nothing by deeds of injury.

7.content: Pride is hateful before God and men: and all iniquity of nations is execrable.

8.content: A kingdom is translated from one people to another, because of injustices, and wrongs, and injuries, and divers deceits.

9.content: But nothing is more wicked than the covetous man. Why is earth, and ashes proud?

10.content: There is not a more wicked thing than to love money: for such a one setteth even his own soul to sale: because while he liveth he hath cast away his bowels.

11.content: All power is of short life. A long sickness is troublesome to the physician.

12.content: The physician cutteth off a short sickness: so also a king is to day, and to morrow he shall die.

13.content: For when a man shall die, he shall inherit serpents, and beasts, and worms.

14.content: The beginning of the pride of man, is to fall off from God:

15.content: Because his heart is departed from him that made him: for pride is the beginning of all sin: he that holdeth it, shall be filled with maledictions, and it shall ruin him in the end.

16.content: Therefore hath the Lord disgraced the assemblies of the wicked, and hath utterly destroyed them.

17.content: God hath overturned the thrones of proud princes, and hath set up the meek in their stead.

18.content: God hath made the roots of proud nations to wither, and hath planted the humble of these nations.

19.content: The Lord hath overthrown the lands of the Gentiles, and hath destroyed them even to the foundation.

20.content: He hath made some of them to wither away, and hath destroyed them, and hath made the memory of them to cease from the earth.

21.content: God hath abolished the memory of the proud, and hath preserved the memory of them that are humble in mind.

22.content: Pride was not made for men: nor wrath for the race of women.

23.content: That seed of men shall be honoured, which feareth God: but that seed shall be dishonoured, which transgresseth the commandments of the Lord.

24.content: In the midst of brethren their chief is honourable: so shall they that fear the Lord, be in his eyes.

25.content: The fear of God is the glory of the rich, and of the honourable, and of the poor.

26.content: Despise not a just man that is poor, and do not magnify a sinful man that is rich.

27.content: The great man, and the judge, and the mighty is in honour: and there is none greater than he that feareth God.

28.content: They that are free shall serve a servant that is wise: and a man that is prudent and well instructed will not murmur when he is reproved; and he that is ignorant, shall not be honoured.

29.content: Extol not thyself in doing thy work, and linger not in the time of distress;

30.content: Better is he that laboureth, and aboundeth in all things, than he that boasteth himself and wanteth bread.

31.content: My son, keep thy soul in meekness, and give it honour according to its desert.

32.content: Who will justify him that sinneth against his own soul? and who will honour him that dishonoureth his own soul?

33.content: The poor man is glorified by his discipline and fear, and there is a man that is honoured for his wealth.

34.content: But he that is glorified in poverty, how much more in wealth? and he that is glorified in wealth, let him fear poverty.

disclaimer: This book is an addition to the Old Testament. It is not found in the Hebrew or Aramaic texts, but are found in the Greek Septuagint and the Latin Vulgate.
